    Another early example of a project at Merck that encountered issues with PXR activation is the bradykinin B1 receptor antagonist project.(234) Derivatives such as 236, Figure 65, were found to activate PXR to a similar extent to rifampicin (99%) in a PXR assay where compounds were screened at 10 μM and PXR activation is expressed relative to that observed for the positive control (rifampicin) also at 10 μM.
    Replacement of the peripheral trifluoromethyl amide was investigated, as exemplified by analogues of 236 in Figure 65. Replacement of the CF3 group by an isoxazole (237) significantly reduced PXR activation while maintaining primary activity. Substitution at the 5-position of the isoxazole of 237 with a methyl group had minimal impact on PXR activity, but larger alkyl groups (ethyl and cyclo-propyl) increased PXR activation (data not shown). The regioisomeric isoxazole 238 had a similar profile with slightly improved primary pharmacology, Figure 65.
    Addition of a methoxy group to the isoxazole of 238 had a further beneficial effect on PXR activity, resulting in 239; however, an ethoxy group or a Cl-atom increased PXR activity (data not shown), thus highlighting the methoxy-isoxazole as optimal.
    Taken together, these results again highlight that reducing lipophilicity at the periphery or compounds can have a beneficial effect on PXR and that addition of further lipophilic groups can be accommodated by PXR and may increase the liability.

    5.4. Merck T-Type Ca2+ Antagonists 2010 (Merck)

    In 2010, the Merck group described some SAR showing the challenges encountered with PXR activation in a series of T-type Ca2+ antagonists.(235) The chemotype was identified from an HTS and came from a series of non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors related to Efavirenz (17), Table 1, which is known to activate PXR. Compounds were again screened in the HepG2 reporter gene assay and were classified as having a high potential for clinical drug–drug interaction with >40% activation at 10 μM, relative to rifampicin), moderate potential with 15% and 40% activation, and low potential with <15% activation. Compounds such as TTA-Q2 (240), Figure 66, showed moderate PXR activation, but as shown by TTA-Q3 (241), replacement of the N-cyclopropyl group by trifluoroethyl significantly increased PXR activity, albeit with the addition of a F-atom in the para-position of the phenyl ring. Replacement of the ethyl group in TTA-Q3 (241) by a cyclopropyl group (TTA-Q5, 242) improved primary activity but exacerbated PXR activation. Introduction of polarity in the para-position of the phenyl ring, which was suggested to reduce PXR activity by molecular modeling, resulted in TTA-Q6 (243) but had minimal impact on PXR activity.
    Due to their overall profiles, TTA-Q3 (241) and TTA-Q6 (243) were profiled in human hepatocytes where they showed 45% and 20% increases in CYP3A4 mRNA, respectively, relative to rifampicin at 1 μM.
    In a subsequent paper, further SAR was described, showing limited impact on PXR activation and highlighting the challenges inherent within this series to balance primary potency and PK and CNS penetration with PXR activation.(236) SAR investigations of the chloro-phenyl ring identified the difluoro-substitution exemplified by 244 as optimal; however, PXR activity was still an issue, Figure 67. Changing the trifluoroethyl group to difluoroethyl made minimal impact (245, Figure 67) but resulted in a compound that was further profiled in vivo due to the optimal balance of other properties. Further attempts to reduce PXR activity, by introducing polarity, included substitution of the N-1 position which resulted in compounds such as 246. Homologation of the ethyl group resulted in 247 which further reduced PXR induction. Both compounds showed low metabolic stability in HLM, while 246 was also found to be a Pgp substrate and therefore not optimal for CNS indications as intended (epilepsy), highlighting the challenges to modulate PXR activity, while balancing other properties in this series.

    5.5. IGF-1R Kinase 2008 and 2010 (BMS)

    While searching for a candidate inhibitor for the insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) kinase, the main series from BMS was found to activate PXR. During the project, the group screened 400 compounds against PXR and published the work detailing the SAR(237) in addition to a paper describing the identification of the candidate molecule, BMS-695735.(238) The SAR paper provides excellent insights to PXR SAR and is one of the few papers to be published exclusively on this topic.
    It was noted that compounds exhibiting 30–40% of the activation of rifampicin at 10 μM were considered to be at risk of inducing CYP3A4; therefore, <30% activation of PXR at 10 μM was targeted. A first-generation compound, BMS-536924 (248) was found to strongly activate PXR, EC50 1.1 μM, Figure 68. In the end, this undesired activity was mitigated by extensive SAR which culminated in the identification of BMS-695735 (249), Figure 68, where two structural modifications were ultimately required to deliver a compound with the desired profile.
    As part of this work, the PXR SAR activation for the two discrete areas of the molecule were published and serve to highlight some valuable modifications that may be of use on other projects. First, targeting the lower part of the molecule, replacement of the meta-chlorophenyl ring with five-membered heterocycles such as pyrazole and imidazole was targeted to reduce lipophilicity. It should be noted that the benzylic alcohol was also deleted. As can be seen, comparing 248 with the chloro-pyrazole analogue 250, Table 5, reveals little change in PXR activation. Interestingly, despite its minimal impact effect on PXR activation, it is this group that was ultimately present in the structure of BMS-695735 (249), Figure 68. Replacing the chloro-pyrazole by the corresponding methyl-pyrazole (251) had minimal impact on IGF-1R potency but substantially reduced PXR transactivation, implying the chlorine atom, or its impact on the electronics of the pyrazole, plays an important role in PXR activation. The unsubstituted pyrazole (252) showed a similar PXR profile but with reduced IGF-1R activity. Incorporation of polar groups (253–255) further reduced PXR transactivation but also diminished IGF-1R activity.
    Table 5. SAR of PXR Activation for Pyrazole and Imidazole Analogues of IGF-1R Inhibitor BMS-536924 from BMS
    Turning to imidazole revealed a similar trend. The dichloro-methylimidazole derivative 256 retained strong PXR transactivation. However, deletion of one chlorine atom (257) substantially alleviated PXR transactivation, which was further enhanced by removal of the second chlorine atom to give 258, Table 5.
    Analysis of the pyrazole and imidazole subseries showed that PXR activation increased with increasing lipophilicity (ACD log D), with compounds requiring a calculated log D ≥ 0.5 for activation of PXR. The analogues profiled had a range of ACD log D values −2.3 to 1.9.
    Investigation of replacements for the morpholine moiety proved extremely fruitful. Simply replacing the morpholine in 248 by a piperazine (259) resulted in a dramatic reduction in PXR transactivation in conjunction with a boost in IGF-1R potency, Table 6. Substitution of the piperazine N-atom resulted in a stepwise increase in PXR transactivation, 260 and 261. The amino pyrrolidine derivatives 262 and 263 show an interesting difference in PXR activity solely due to the inversion of the stereocenter. Switching the piperazine to a substituted piperidine such as 264 or 265 showed PXR activity could also be maintained at a low level with larger groups, although this is likely to be due to the polarity of these groups as the 1,3-dioxolane derivative 266 showed potent PXR transactivation.
    Table 6. SAR of PXR Activation for a Morpholine Analogues of IGF-1R Inhibitor BMS-536924 (248) from BMS
    In this subseries, a plot of ACD log D versus PXR activation revealed no correlation, implying the reduced PXR activation for analogues is due to a detrimental structural interaction with PXR. In addition, the range of ACD log D values reflected the higher lipophilicity of these derivatives (ACD log D range ∼0.5–4.0), with one derivative showing ACD log D ∼4.0 with negligible PXR activation.
    As this work had highlighted the impact of the piperidine-piperazine moiety (265) as a replacement for the morpholine and the potential of the chloro-pyrazole (250) and chloro-imidazole (257) ring systems in the southern region, several combination derivatives were investigated, two of which, 267 and 268, are shown in Figure 69. As can be seen from the PXR activation data for both, the combination provided a similarly low level of PXR activation.
    Although these derivatives provided low levels of PXR activation, in the end the group returned to substituted piperazines in combination with the chloro-pyrazole, which ultimately resulted in the identification of 249, Figure 68, which displayed the required balance and combination of properties.

    5.6. NOP Antagonists (Schering-Plough 2009)

    In search for nociceptin (NOP) agonists for the treatment of cough and anxiety, researchers at Schering-Plough identified tropane derivatives which were found to activate PXR.(239) Compounds were screened in a human PXR reporter gene assay at 1 μM, and data were reported as activation relative to the positive control, rifampicin also at 1 μM. A ratio of <0.4 of rifampicin at 1 μM was targeted. Compound 269 was found to exhibit a ratio of 0.89 relative to rifampicin and therefore deemed to have a considerable risk of CYP3A4 induction. Substitution at the para-position of the phenyl ring, as highlighted in Figure 70, was found to reduce PXR activation, regardless of the nature of the substituent, thereby implying a steric interaction with PXR. Several derivatives are highlighted in Figure 70 to exemplify this. For instance, a F-atom (270) shows a marked reduction of PXR activity and again highlights the worthiness of fluorine substitution when wishing to reduce PXR activity. Chlorine, 271, showed a further reduction, but no subsequent benefit was observed with Br (data not shown). A methoxy group had a similar effect to Cl, as shown by 272. Other polar groups, e.g., a primary amide (not shown), also had a similar activity on PXR but diminished NOP activity.
    It was found that amide substitution generally worsened PXR activation. Thus methylation of 269 resulted in 273, which showed an inferior PXR profile. This was further exacerbated by the ethyl analogue 274 and even further by the iso-propyl derivative 275. Incorporation of some polarity did not improve the situation, as shown by 276; however, it should be noted that this derivative could form an intramolecular hydrogen bond, thus masking polarity and resulting in less steric demand.

    5.7. Smoothened Antagonists (Amgen, 2010)

    In 2010 Amgen, disclosed issues with PXR activation for a series of smoothened antagonists.(240) Compounds such as 277 were found to activate PXR in a HepG2 luciferase reporter assay where it showed 81% activation at 2 μM, relative to the positive control, rifampicin. Deletion of the trifluoromethyl group (278) reduced PXR activation to 30% at 2 μM, Figure 71. Interestingly, deletion of the methyl group on the piperazine also reduced PXR activation (279), whereas moving it on the piperazine ring (280) had no effect, implicating a role of lipophilicity in the PXR interaction. This was further supported by the replacement of the trifluoromethyl group in 277 by a hydroxymethyl moiety (281) which also reduced lipophilicity and PXR activation.
    Interestingly, replacement of the left-hand phenyl ring by pyridine did not impact PXR activation despite the reduction in lipophilicity, thereby contesting the thesis that the PXR activity of the series was driven by lipophilicity, 281–283, Figure 72. The three pyridyl isomers also showed decreased smoothened activity (>10-fold). Both 2-pyrazine (5.4% of control at 2 μM) and 5-pyrimidine (7.1% of control at 2 μM) analogues did show reduced PXR activation but were inactive at smoothened (not shown). Thus, this SAR against PXR is reminiscent of that seen by Merck on their series of 11β-HSD1 inhibitors, section 5.2, Figures 54 and 55 and suggests that this SAR could be implemented on other series if the primary target is accepting.
    On the contrary, replacement of the phenyl moiety of the phthalazine by pyridine had a beneficial effect on PXR with all 4 isomers showing reduced activity, as shown for the conversion of 278 to 284–287, Figure 73. As only 286 retained the same level of potency, this isomer was selected for reincorporation of the trifluoromethyl group on the left-hand side and resulted in 288, which was ultimately profiled further and corroborated the beneficial effect of the N-atom, Figure 73.

    5.8. NaV1.7 (Amgen, 2017)

    Identification and optimization of NaV1.7 inhibitors for the treatment of pain has been an area of intense focus for many pharmaceutical companies in recent years. The ligands identified are typically aryl sulfonamides, containing a heteroaromatic amine, usually a thiazole or thiadiazole. These ligands bear some structural similarity with those from Xenon that inhibit NaV1.6 and activate PXR and alerted the group at Xenon to explore the PXR activation of the series, vide supra (section 3.7). Toward this end, researchers at Amgen have recently reported efforts on their series of compounds and the challenges encountered, including PXR activation.(241,242) Compounds from this class faced several further challenges, such as formation of GSH adducts upon incubation in HLMs, attributed to the aminothiazole, CYP3A4 inhibition, and high plasma protein binding. Furthermore, it was found that attempts to reduce lipophilicity resulted in higher in vivo clearance, which was attributed to increased biliary clearance and ultimately found to be due to compounds being substrates for hepatobiliary transporters such as organic anion-transporting polypeptide 1B1 (OATP1B1) and multidrug resistance-associated protein 2 (MRP2).
    In terms of PXR/CYP3A4 induction, compounds such as the quinazoline 289 were found to increase CYP3A4 levels more than rifampicin, when incubated at 10 μM (levels are expressed as the percentage of rifampicin, also at 10 μM), Figure 74. The aminothiazole could be replaced by a 4-aminpyrimidine (with a switch to an isoquinoline template), 290, to alleviate GSH adduct formation, albeit with a decrease in primary activity, but this potentiated CYP3A4 induction. A breakthrough was achieved when the trifluoromethyl group was replaced by a substituted phenyl ring, such as the meta-fluorophenyl ring in 291, Figure 74.
    Primary potency could be improved by adding a Cl-atom para-to the methoxy group to give 292, which also maintained relatively low CYP3A4 induction. Further analogues of 292 were prepared to investigate replacements of the 4-aminopyrimidine, a selection of which (293–296) are shown in Figure 74.
    Six-membered aromatic diazines, such as 293, had little impact or slightly exacerbated the CYP3A4 induction. However, five-membered rings such as thiadiazole 294 and oxadiazole 295 showed markedly reduced induction, which could in part be attributed to their reduced clog D. Removal of a N-atom from 295 to give 296 resulted in increased induction. Despite this, the isoxazole sulfonamide series was selected for further exploration as it showed lower in vivo clearance (rat and dog) than other derivatives, and as compounds are acidic and therefore have low volumes of distribution, it was considered that achieving a reasonable half-life would be driven by low clearance. As such, the SAR was investigated in other regions of the molecule in an attempt to mitigate CYP3A4 induction.
    Replacement of the isoquinoline core by alternative bicycles designed to reduce clog D had little impact. Therefore, attention turned to the southern fluoro-phenyl ring, where varying the substitution pattern proved more fruitful. A first step was to switch the Cl and F-atoms on 296, resulting in 297, with a moderate, beneficial effect on PXR activation, Figure 75. Replacing the meta-chlorophenyl ring of 297 by a meta-toluyl (298) was not favorable. However, addition of a Cl-atom in the para-position resulted in 299 which displayed almost no PXR activation, Figure 75. It was also found that replacement of the meta-chlorophenyl ring of 297 by a meta-trifluoromethyl phenyl ring (300) also completely negated PXR activation. This structural modification can also be viewed as the replacement of the methyl group in 298 by a trifluoromethyl group (300). Finally, the methoxy pyridine derivative (301) proved detrimental and significantly increased PXR activation.
    The benefit of the meta-trifluoromethyl substitution was again highlighted by two matched pairs, 302 to 303 and 304 to 305, highlighted in Figure 76, thus demonstrating the utility of this transformation within this series. These compounds also highlight that the addition of a nitrile group on the inner phenyl ring did not impact PXR activation, compare 302 to 304 and 303 to 305, Figure 76.
    Due to the challenges encountered in balancing all parameters within this subseries, particularly in vivo clearance, PXR activation, and CYP2C9 inhibition, it was decided to investigate other templates to replace the isoquinoline. Ultimately this resulted in the quinolinone core which was subsequently utilized for optimization. Compound 306, Figure 77, is the direct analogue of isoquinoline 302, Figure 76, but shows a slightly better profile due to its increased potency and weaker PXR activation. Substitution para-to the methoxy group on the inner phenyl ring increased PXR activation (307–309), Figure 77, although the F-derivative 307, had less impact than the Cl (308) or the methyl (309) analogues.
    Even though a F-atom para-to the methoxy group increased PXR activation, it was found that this could be mitigated by substituents in the para-position of the outer phenyl ring. Thus, 3,4-difluorophenyl derivative 310, representing a very subtle change from 307, showed minimal PXR activation, as did the 3-fluoro-4-cyano derivative 311, Figure 77.
    The effect of para-substitution was further emphasized by the three isomeric trifluoromethyl derivatives, 312–314, Figure 78, which shows the ortho-analogue (312) substantially increases PXR activation, whereas meta-substitution (313) significantly atones PXR activation while para-substitution (314) essentially abolishes it. It is interesting to note that the meta-trifluoromethyl group did not have the same impact on PXR activity in this series (313) as it did in the isoquinoline series (300, Figure 75).
    The beneficial effect of a bulky meta-substituent was confirmed by 315, while combining meta- and para-substituents resulted in 316, which could be further improved by increasing the size of the para-substituent (317), Figure 78. Thus, the 4-chloro-3-methyl outer phenyl ring was found to reduce PXR activity in both the quinolinone series (317, Figure 78) and the isoquinoline series (299, Figure 75).
    The beneficial effect of the 3,4-disubstitution pattern on PXR activation was transferable to other heteroaromatic sulfonamides, such as 318 and 319, Figure 79. Deletion of the F-atom para-to the methoxy group had no effect (not shown) and the regioisomeric pyrimidine further exemplified the 3,4-disubstitution on the outer phenyl ring (320). Ultimately AM-0466 (321) with the meta-trifluoromethyl group provided the best balance between PXR activation, primary activity, and CYP2C9 and CYP3A4 inhibition.

    5.9. IDH1 Inhibitors (Agios, 2018)

    While optimizing inhibitors of isocitrate dehydrogenase 1 (IDH1), the Agios group discovered that compounds from their series, as typified by 322, Figure 80,(243) activated PXR. Adding a polar hydroxyl group to the pyrroglutamide moiety made little impact, 323. However, the same modification in combination with addition of a nitrogen atom (conversion of the pyridine to a pyrimidine) resulted in 324 with significantly diminished PXR activity but suboptimal cellular activity. Switching attention to the upper part of the molecule, replacement of a fluorine atom by a sulfonamide, 325, drastically reduced PXR activation but resulted in high microsomal clearance. More positively, replacement of the difluoro phenyl ring by a fluoropyridine, 326, also had the desired impact on PXR activity. 326 showed a modest decrease in exposure upon repeat dosing in rodent toxicology studies; it did not show reduced exposure in monkey studies. In human clinical studies, 326 showed a long half-life and accumulation upon repeat dosing. However, it also increased CYP3A4 enzyme activity at its recommended dose (500 mg q.d.), which is suggestive of CYP3A4 induction via PXR activation.(244) This compound ultimately progressed through clinical trials and has since been launched.

    5.10. P2X3 Antagonists (Merck, 2018)

    P2X3 is a ligand-gated (ATP) ion channel, believed to play a role in pain sensation, for which Merck identified the antagonist MK-3901 (327) as a development candidate,(245)Figure 81. However, several issues were subsequently identified with this compound, including a potential DDI risk via activation of PXR. To identify improved analogues, further compounds were prepared, with the goal of also improving the metabolic stability via replacement of the labile groups, primarily the methyl group on the upper pyridine ring and the isoxazoline. It was found that the isoxazoline-pyridine moiety on the right-hand side could be replaced by much smaller groups, such as fluoropyridine, 328, Figure 81; however, this instilled potent PXR activation. Interestingly the morpholine ring, 329, ablated PXR activity, whereas the isopropanol derivative, 330, resulted in potent PXR activity despite the presence of the polar hydroxy group.
    Despite the potent PXR activity associated with 330, it was selected for further optimization due to its reduced plasma protein binding. Interestingly, changing the 3-fluoropyridine on the left-hand side of 330 to the 2-trifluoromethylpyridine in 331 reduced PXR activation by 8-fold, Figure 82. Conversion of the pyridine to its N-oxide, 332, further improved the PXR profile. Finally, replacement of the metabolically labile methyl group in the northern region by a chlorine atom delivered 333 with no worsening of PXR activity, Figure 82.
    Thus, from this work, the beneficial effect of a morpholine ring in place of an aromatic ring can be seen. Also, employing a polar group, such as a pyridine N-oxide can be very effective, but also replacing a F-atom by a trifluoromethyl group may also suffice, although this could in part be due to the isomeric pyridine on which the group was appended.

    5.11. TRPM8 Antagonists (Amgen, 2018)

    PXR activation was identified as an undesired off-target activity by the group at Amgen during the optimization of a series of TRPM8 antagonists for the treatment of migraines.(246) Thus 334, Figure 83, was found to activate PXR and thereby increase CYP3A4 mRNA levels in human hepatocytes following 5 days incubation, with the response shown relative to rifampicin at 10 μM. The strategy implemented by the group to reduce the CYP3A4 induction was to lower lipophilicity or introduce polarity on the periphery of the molecules. To this end, it was found that the right-hand side quinoline could be truncated to give the benzamide 335, Figure 83, with a marginal improvement in 3A4 induction. Replacement of the phenyl ring by the more polar pyridone, 336, effectively decreased lipophilicity and reduced 3A4 induction. Replacement of the CF3 group on the left-hand pyridine by a fluorine, 337, further reduced lipophilicity and alleviated 3A4 induction, Figure 83, supporting the overall strategy.
    In order to further improve the profile of 337, several further structural modifications were implemented, summarized in Figure 84. Altering the substitution on the southern phenyl ring did not impact 3A4 induction (338). Replacing the pyridone by a nicotinic acid, 339, reduced lipophilicity substantially but did not significantly impact CYP3A4 induction. Ultimately however, the compounds shown in Figure 84 had the best overall profiles from this series. As a result, these compounds were profiled in rat PK studies and an ex vivo rabbit heart cardiovascular (CV) assay, where 337 displayed a very narrow therapeutic index (TI) relative to in vivo efficacy. While 338 displayed a better CV TI (59-fold), it was 339 (AMG 333) which displayed the best TI (>420-fold) and was selected as a development candidate.

    5.12. CFTR Correctors (AbbVie, 2018–2019)

    While optimizing a series of compounds as correctors of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein, i.e., compounds which correct the folding of mutant CFTR and result in increased channel expression and function in the cell membrane, it was found that members of the series could cause induction of CYP3A4.(247) It was already known that the CFTR corrector from Vertex, Lumacaftor (8, Table 1), induced CYP 3A4 expression,(248) which may have raised a flag due to the somewhat related chemical structure. To assess the extent of CYP3A4 induction, cryopreserved human hepatocytes were incubated with compounds for 48 h and the increase in CYP3A4 mRNA was expressed relative to that of rifampicin at 10 μM, with <20% induction relative to rifampicin considered a low potential for 3A4 induction. In this assay, 340, Figure 85, showed low levels of induction. Some close analogues were tested and revealed that moving the methoxy group, 341, had minimal impact, whereas replacing the methoxy group in 340 by CF3, 342, or even a fluorine atom, 343, exacerbated the induction, Figure 85.
    Further modification of 340 demonstrated that moving the carboxylic acid from the meta- to the para-position resulted in a dramatic increase in potency and completely negated CYP3A4 induction, 344, Figure 86. Ultimately, replacement of the methoxy group by a difluoro methoxy group resulted in 345 (ABBV/GLPG-2222), which maintained minimal CYP3A4 induction and had a suitable overall profile to be selected as a development compound.
    A subsequent paper from the same group has outlined further SAR from a different series, exemplified by 346, which showed strong CYP3A4 induction, Figure 87.(249) Fortunately, simple analogues of the southern amide, such as isopropyl carbamate 347 or tetrahydropyranyl amide 348, almost ablated CYP3A4 induction, Figure 87.
    Further optimization of primary activity by addition of ortho-substituents to the eastern phenyl ring resulted in a marked increase in PXR activity, such as the ethyl derivative 349, whereas the chloro-analogue 350 had minimal impact, at least at a lower concentration, Figure 88.
    Ultimately the balance between potency and CYP3A4 induction was met by the ortho-methyl derivative 351 (ABBV/GLPG-3221), although in this case CYP3A4 induction was measured at 1 μM, Figure 88.

    5.13. RORγ (Phenex, Janssen, BMS 2018–2020)

    The identification of inverse agonists of the retinoic acid-related orphan receptor γ (RORγ) for the treatment of T-cell mediated diseases has been a long standing goal within the pharmaceutical industry, due to its potential to lower inflammatory modulators such as IL-17. As highlighted in this perspective, one of the challenges that has plagued the clinical advancement of compounds for this target is the activation of PXR, which is a closely related nuclear receptor to RORγ. To this end researchers from Phenex in collaboration with Janssen have recently reported some of their work in the area, including data and SAR on PXR activation, which is summarized herein.
    The initial series was exemplified by 352,(250)Figure 89 and showed good levels of potency in a cell assay measuring ROR-mediated transcription but also showed strong PXR activation at 1 and 10 μM. Attempts to reduce PXR activity by replacement of the THP moiety by more polar groups, such as 353 and 354, Figure 89, were unable to impact this undesired activity, showing that increasing polarity in the periphery of a series does not work universally.
    Turning to the naphthyl group revealed some interesting SAR, Figure 90. An additional heteroatom, 355, provided a moderate improvement in PXR activation. On the other hand, reduction of the outer phenyl ring, 356, almost abolished PXR activation, as did replacement of the northern phenyl ring by two Cl-atoms, 357. Interestingly, when only one Cl-atom was used, 358, PXR activation returned.
    As the tert-butyl sulfonamide group was implicated in the formation of glutathione adducts in metabolite identification studies, it was ultimately replaced by an (S)-1,1,1-trifluoropropyl amine. This change, coupled with a shift to a modified template, Figure 91, exemplified by 359, revealed some disparities in PXR SAR.(251) Replacing the naphthyl moiety by the isosteric dichlorophenyl, 360, again had a positive impact on PXR activation. One carbon elongation of the sulfonamide group (361) had little impact; however, deletion of a Cl-atom (362) markedly reduced PXR activation, in contrast to 358 above, Figure 90, but also reduced primary activity. Replacement of the Cl-atoms in 361 by an F-atom and a difluoro methyl group resulted in 363 which displayed much less PXR activation. This compound maintained low PXR activation at 5 μM and almost negligible PXR activation at 1 μM. The low levels of PXR activation also translated to low CYP3A4 induction at 1 and 10 μM. A further diversified analogue, 364, was also identified as part of this work, which had an amide in place of the methyl-cyclobutyl group and an isopropanol moiety in place of the lipophilic alkyl acid group on the left-hand side. Although 364 showed low levels of PXR activation, it induced CYP3A4 levels, at 10 μM, to a higher extent than 363, Figure 91.
    In order to further profile 363 and 364, both were progressed to rat 5 day tolerability studies at 300 mg/kg (363) and 1000 mg/kg (364). It was found that both compounds showed lower exposure on day 5 than day 1, also implicating rodent PXR activation and CYP450 induction as the likely cause, ultimately resulting in autoinduction. On day 1, 363 had a Cmax of 303 000 ng/mL and AUC of 4 710 000 h ng/mL, whereas on day 5 the Cmax had dropped to 151 000 ng/mL (51% reduction) and the AUC had decreased to 1 790 000 h ng/mL (62% reduction). Similarly, for 364, the Cmax on day 1 was 24 500 ng/mL and the AUC was 274 000 h ng/mL, whereas on day 5 the Cmax had dropped to 3160 ng/mL (87% reduction) and the AUC had decreased to 51 000 h ng/mL (82% reduction). Thus, the marked decrease in exposure over the 5 day dosing period with both compounds did not support their progression. As can be seen from the in vivo exposure data, the plasma concentrations are high for both compounds, with total plasma Cmax values of approximately 463 μM and 36 μM on day 1 for 363 and 364, respectively.
    Subsequent work from the same group produced extensive PXR activation SAR for the series; however, only a few compounds are summarized as in general the structural modifications did not substantially impact this issue.(252) Ultimately, another compound was progressed to rat 5 day tolerability studies but also showed decreased exposure upon repeat administration. This time round, the PXR activation of compounds was assessed at 1, 5, or 10 μM, some at a single concentration, some at more than one. Most of the described compounds utilized the dichlorophenyl central motif seen in 360, Figure 91, but with an amide in place of the oxadiazole, which utilizes the 1-amino-2-methyl-propan-2-ol group identified by BMS to reduce PXR activation in their CCR1 antagonist, vide supra, section 3.3, and RORγ inverse agonist work, vide supra, section 3.6. Much of the SAR explored involved variations of the amide in the southern region of the molecule. In all, 33 amide analogues were assessed, 19 of which contained cyclic amines, a selection of which are shown in Figure 92. The difluoro-piperidine, as seen in 364, Figure 91, proved one of the best groups to moderate PXR activation as shown by 365. The unsubstituted piperidine analogue, 366, or the 4-methylpiperidine analogues, 367, showed more pronounced PXR activation, highlighting a beneficial effect of the F-atoms. The monofluoropiperidine 368 showed similar PXR activation to 365 but was almost 5-fold more potent at RORγ and ultimately proved to be the optimal compound from this investigation. The analogous difluoropyrrolidine, 369, did however maintain similar PXR activation levels to 365, Figure 92.
    Variation of the sulfonamide substituent was investigated but also had little impact on PXR activation. Fixing the 4-fluoropiperidine in 368 and varying the substituent on the left-hand side amide had some, albeit limited impact, Figure 93. For example, truncation to the primary amide 370 significantly increased PXR activation. Rigid, polar groups such as that in 371 reduced PXR activation but also reduced RORγ activity. Replacement of the alcohol by a nitrile (372) was neutral as was reversal of the amide (373). Thus, no structural changes were identified that diminished PXR activity without having a parallel impact on RORγ activity.
    The SAR shown highlight the challenges to negate PXR activation within this series. Most structural modifications resulted in minimal moderation of PXR activity, despite some substantial structural changes and sampling each region of the molecule. Based on its overall profile, 368 was profiled in more detail. A dose response experiment revealed an EC50 of 1.7 μM at PXR. Efficacy studies in mice demonstrated a 60% reduction in IL-17A levels ex vivo 1 h after an oral dose of 30 mg/kg with plasma concentrations approximately 1700 ng/mL (∼2900 nM, ∼330 nM free). Compound 368 was progressed to a 14 day oral tolerability study in the rat at doses of 50 and 200 mg/kg b.i.d. (i.e., 100 mg/kg and 400 mg/kg total per day) where it showed > 90% reduction in exposure over the duration of the study; 50 mg/kg day 0 Cmax 11 200 ng/mL (approximately 19.1 μM total/2.2 μM free), AUC 31 500 ng h/mL versus day 4 Cmax 252 ng/mL, AUC 870 ng h/mL; 200 mg/kg b.i.d. day 0 Cmax 49 400 ng/mL, AUC 282 000 ng h/mL versus day 4 Cmax 1900 ng/mL, AUC 6000 ng h/mL. The exposures on day 14 were similar to those on day 4 indicating that 4 days of administration is sufficient to pick up exposure changes related to autoinduction. Analysis of the livers from this study revealed that CYP3a1 and CYP2b1 gene levels were upregulated by 18-fold at the 50 mg/kg b.i.d. dose, supporting the loss of exposure due to PXR activation (at least in part) and autoinduction. A subsequent study in rat hepatocytes showed that 368 increased CYP3a23 mRNA by approximately 5-fold at 1 μM and approximately 10-fold at 10 μM, relative to an approximate 7-fold increase for the positive control dexamethasone at 10 μM. Both concentrations of 368 resulted in increased conversion of testosterone to 6β-hydroxy testosterone, approximately 10-fold and 15-fold, respectively. This assay was therefore utilized to help identify compounds with reduced PXR activation/CYP3a induction, the results of which are due to be published.
    In addition to the work detailed in the SBDD section, the group at BMS have also used empirical approaches to try to reduce PXR activation for one series of RORγ inverse agonists. The series, exemplified by 374,(253)Figure 94, was spurned by scaffold hopping initiatives to mimic the conformation of compounds such as 114 and 115, Figure 30 and 75 and 117, Figure 31. As with other RORγ series identified by BMS, 374 was a potent activator of PXR. Replacement of the acetyl group by more polar groups was investigated to try to diminish PXR activation, but the methyl sulfonamide and ethyl carbamate analogues had no impact on PXR activity (data not shown). The ethyl urea (375) provided some improvement whereas the benzyl urea (376) again increased PXR activity, Figure 94. Interestingly, moving the methyl group on the piperidine (376 and 377) significantly increased PXR activation.
    The acetyl piperidine group (378), also employed in other series, vide supra, (section 3.6, 118, Figure 31) also diminished PXR activity.
    Further exploration of this series included the addition of polar groups at the para-position of the benzyl group, using the fluorophenyl analogue of 376, i.e., 379, Figure 95. Surprisingly, this substitution increased PXR activity, for example, the cyano derivative 380, or more strikingly, the ethyl sulfone 381 which showed approximately a 112-fold increase in PXR activity over 379. The impact of the ethyl sulfone on PXR activity is noteworthy, given this group showed a profound benefit when utilized by Merck in the series of 11β-HSD1 inhibitors, vide supra, e.g., 187, Figure 53, section 5.2.
    Returning to the acetylpiperidine moiety, this time as an enantiomerically pure fluorinated phenyl analogue, 382, Figure 96, fluorination of the alcohol moiety (383) essentially abolished PXR activity, indicating the importance of this functional group in the interaction with PXR. Although in this instance RORγ activity was also markedly decreased, this transformation was transferable and utilized in other series, which ultimately resulted in a clinical development candidate, vide supra BMS-986251 (129), Figure 35, and 122, Figure 33, section 3.6. Additional attempts to increase polarity by modification of the acetyl group had little impact on PXR activity, e.g., 384, or actually increased PXR activity, 385, Figure 96. Despite its more potent PXR activity, 385 was profiled further, based on its enhanced RORγ activity, metabolic stability and also due to its decreased Ymax at PXR.

    5.14. DOT1L (Novartis 2019)

    Although not containing detailed in vitro SAR on PXR activation, a recent paper from the Novartis group highlights some in vivo SAR around autoinduction, ultimately via CYP450a induction, for a series of disruptor of telomeric silencing 1-like protein (DOT1L) inhibitors.(254) Profiling of 386 and 387, Figure 97, revealed interesting results; however, both were found to exhibit reduced exposure when administered orally over a period of several days. Thus, for 386, a single oral dose of 100 mg/kg to mice resulted in a Cmax of 24 μM and an AUC0–12h of 216 h μM, whereas when administered at 100 mg/kg b.i.d. for 20 days the Cmax decreased modestly, to 12 μM, whereas the AUC dropped significantly, to 47 h μM (measured on day 20). In this instance, the reduction in the AUC appeared to be mainly driven by the shape of the AUC curve, i.e., the clearance. Follow up studies in rat and human hepatocyte assays supported the potential link between decreased exposure and P450 induction.
    A subtle switch in structure from 387 to 388 (changing methoxy to piperazine) or 389 (changing methyl sulfone to primary sulfonamide in conjunction with methoxy to amino group), Figure 97, proved sufficient to alleviate the CYP induction. Thus, administration of 388 at a dose of 300 mg/kg q.d. for 7 days showed no decrease in exposure and, in fact, actually showed some degree of accumulation (Cmax ∼11 μM) compared to a single dose (Cmax ∼8 μM). While the AUC curves are almost identical in shape, confirming no change in clearance, it cannot be concluded if this effect is due to reduced potency for CYP induction or due to the lower Cmax. However, as the Cmax values are approximately within 2-fold for 386 and 388, it appears reasonable to attribute the effect to a reduced potency for CYP induction of 388. Similarly, dosing of 389 for 7 days at 50 mg/kg s.c. revealed that exposure was maintained, although no further details were provided. Caution should be taken in the interpretation of the data for 389 as it contains a sulfonamide rather than a sulfone and could simply be a decrease in plasma exposure due to increased blood cell partitioning.
    Thus, the subtle structural changes shown in this example again serve to highlight the profound effect apparently small changes can have on CYP induction.

    5.15. HBV Capsid Inhibitors (Roche 2019)

    More recently, Roche encountered CYP3A4 induction with HBV compounds that inhibit the assembly of the core protein to a normal nucleocapsid. Compound 390 (HAP_R10) was advanced to clinical trials but was found to induce CYP3A4 in human hepatocytes, which was confirmed in a PhI study (Figure 98). In order to identify compounds without CYP3A4 induction, the team conducted further SAR within the series.(255) To assess CYP3A4 induction, compounds were incubated with human hepatocytes for 24 h, with rifampicin as the positive control at 10 μM. CYP3A4 mRNA was measured as the assay read out. For routine screening, compounds were tested at a single concentration (10 μM), but compounds of interest were profiled at 1 and 0.1 μM in addition. CYP3A4 induction of less than 40% of that of rifampicin at 10 μM was targeted, based on a combination of experience within Roche and FDA guidance.(134)
    The conformation of a close analogue of 390, 391 (HAP_R01), bound to the capsid protein revealed that the halogenated phenyl ring is pseudoaxial and its plane is perpendicular to the dihydropyrimidine ring, likely influenced by the ortho-chlorine atom on the phenyl ring and the fact that the ester is also in the plane of the dihydropyrimidine (Figure 99). The thiazole is also in the plane of the dihydropyrimidine, likely due to positive interactions between the S-atom and the N-atom of the dihydropyrimidine and the N-atom of the thiazole with the NH of the dihydropyrimidine, and this is similar to small molecule crystal structures, e.g., CCDC No. 1012347.
    In an effort to mitigate PXR induction via modulation of the phenyl substitution, several analogues were made, the key SAR of which is highlighted in Table 7. First, shifting from the methyl ester in 390 to an ethyl ester, as shown by 392 increased CYP3A4 induction: 111% versus 173%, respectively, which could be related to the increased lipophilicity. Changing from a 2-chloro-4-fluorophenyl substitution to 2,4-difluoro, 393, had little impact. The 4-fluorophenyl derivative 394 showed less induction, but when an additional fluorine atom was added in the 3-position to give 395 the CYP3A4 induction was markedly diminished.
    Table 7. Variation of the Substitution of the Phenyl Ring in a Series of HBV Capsid Inhibitors from Roche Showed a Surprising Variation in CYP3A4 Induction
    Larger substituents than fluorine in the 3-position were not tolerated as they resulted in a loss of potency against HBV, but the 3-fluoro-4-methyl analogue, 396, confirmed the beneficial effect of fluorine at the 3-position. However, a 3-fluorine alone was insufficient to mitigate CYP3A4 induction, 397, and thus it seems that a 3-fluorine in conjunction with another group at the 4-position is optimal.
    As it was known that utilizing the methyl ester rather than the ethyl ester should also have a beneficial effect on CYP3A4 induction, as demonstrated by 390 versus 392, reversion to the methyl ester analogue of 395, i.e., 398, Figure 100, was investigated, but no significant improvement was observed. Finally, replacement of the 4-fluorine by a Cl-atom resulted in 399, Figure 100, which proved optimal in terms of CYP3A4 induction and primary activity. Confirmation of reduced CYP3A4 induction potential was confirmed in a dose–response assay in human hepatocytes. In addition to measuring CYP3A4 mRNA in this assay, it was also shown that there was no increase in CYP1A2 or CYP2B6 mRNA. A small molecule crystal structure of 399 revealed the substituted phenyl ring to be approximately orthogonal to that of 391, which was postulated to be responsible for the reduced CYP3A4 induction. It was hypothesized that there may be an enthalpy penalty for the phenyl ring to achieve the optimal orientation to bind to PXR or that the conformation shown by the small molecule crystal structure may sterically hinder the N-atom in the dihydropyrimidine from accepting a hydrogen bond in PXR.
    Overall, this work nicely describes how very subtle modifications can often influence CYP3A4 induction and PXR activity; the net result of switching from a 2-chloro-4-fluorophenyl ring to a 4-chloro-3-fluorophenyl ring was a dramatic reduction in CYP3A4 induction, highlighted in Figure 101.
    Whether this is due to specific detrimental interactions with PXR, a loss of an HBA interaction or a subtle change in rotation of the phenyl ring remains unknown but serves to highlight that seemingly small structural changes are worth considering along with the associated effect on conformers.

    5.16. EZH2 Inhibitors (Constellation, 2020)

    Inhibition of enhancer of zeste homologue 2 (EZH2), which trimethylates lysine 27 of histone 3 (H3K27), has been a target of interest within the pharmaceutical industry for a significant period of time, due to its potential for the treatment of various types of oncology. Several inhibitors have now been evaluated in human clinical trials but some, such as CPI-1205 (400), from Constellation, have been found to show reduced exposure after multiple dosing, due to induction of CYP3A4. CYP induction may be an inherent issue with the pharmacophore, given that other EZH2 inhibitors such as Tazemetostat (29), Table 1, have been found to induce CYP3A4 in the clinic. The CYP induction for CPI-1205 (400) presented a problem in terms of achieving efficacy as preclinical data showed that prolonged treatment was required to elicit the required reduction of H3K27. In order to mitigate this issue with second generation compounds, the Constellation group targeted prolonged EZH2 inhibition by increasing the residence time of inhibitors on EZH2 and by reducing their potential to induce CYP3A4 expression.(256) Investigation of the pyridine SAR of CPI-1205 (400) revealed that the methylthioether analogue 401 showed improved potency and residence time, Figure 102, but still showed strong induction of CYP3A4, in immortalized human hepatocytes (Fa2N-4 cells). Switching from the trifluoroethyl piperidine moiety to an oxetane (402), with the aim of reducing lipophilicity, revealed a dramatic reduction in CYP3A4 induction, Figure 102. Moving the piperidine N-atom to give the cyclohexyl derivative with a difluoro azetidine (403) reintroduced CYP induction. However, the oxetane analogue 404 again mitigated this liability. Simply converting the difluoro-azetidine of 403 to a methoxy azetidine (405) also mitigated the CYP induction, which could be due to a reduction in lipophilicity (403 clog D 3.8, 405 clog D 3.3) which in turn could be via modulation of the azetidine basicity. Replacing the cyclohexane by 1,3-dioxane (406) also diminished CYP3A4 upregulation, although in this case a dimethylamine substituent was employed. Within this subseries, there appeared to be a correlation between CYP3A4 upregulation and clog D.
    Although 405 was dosed for 21 days in a mouse lymphoma model at 50 mg/kg b.i.d. s.c., exposure data and CYP3a levels were not reported, thus it is not possible to conclude if autoinduction was an issue in vivo in the mouse. However, the effect of 405 on inhibition of tumor volume growth appeared to persist for the duration of the study, which may imply exposure was maintained at least above the therapeutically active concentrations although it does not rule out some decrease. As further profiling of 405 revealed no bioavailability, further optimization was conducted.
    Focusing on 405 revealed that addition of fluorine atoms, 407 and 408, or enlargement to a cyclopropyl group, 409, resulted in increased CYP3A4 regulation, Figure 103. Fluorination of the methoxy group provides a striking increase in CYP34A upregulation. All these structural modifications resulted in an increase in clog D which may, at least in part, contribute to this activity. The cyclopropyl derivative, 409, also adds partial π-character which may contribute.
    Despite its increased propensity to upregulate CYP3A4, cyclopropyl ether 409 was selected for further optimization, perhaps due to its long residence time. Modification of the central indole, with the goal of reducing lipophilicity to mitigate CYP3A4 upregulation resulted in azaindole derivatives 410–412, Figure 104. Interestingly, the unsubstituted azaindole 410 and its chlorinated analogue, 411, showed a marked reduction in CYP3A4 upregulation compared to 409. Surprisingly, the fluoro-substituted analogue 412 showed much higher CYP3A4 upregulation compared to 410 or 411, implying an important role of the fluorine atom in 3A4 induction and ultimately PXR interaction. This subtle modification again highlights the surprising SAR that can be uncovered when trying to mitigate PXR activity. Often a fluorine atom is beneficial whereas the more lipophilic Cl-atom increases PXR activity (as highlighted elsewhere in this perspective). The SAR of this subseries also revealed no correlation between clog D and CYP3A4 upregulation, again supporting a specific molecular interaction.
    Ultimately, 410 was selected for further profiling based on its overall profile. Repeat dosing, 25 mg/kg b.i.d. p.o. for 21 days resulted in strong inhibition of tumor growth in a mouse lymphoma model, but again no exposure data was disclosed.

    5.17. Orexin-1 (OX1) Antagonists (Janssen, 2020)

    A recent disclosure from the Janssen group highlighted an issue with PXR activation encountered with a series of azabicyclo[2.2.1]heptanes, as selective orexin-1 (OX1) antagonists for the treatment of CNS disorders such as addiction, panic, or anxiety.(257) Profiling advanced leads revealed moderate PXR induction potential, Figure 105. Compound 413 activated PXR which resulted in an 18% induction of CYP3A4 relative to that of rifampicin at 10 μM. Addition of a fluorine atom to 413 resulted in 414, which showed a slight increase in PXR activation, Figure 105. Switching the trifluoromethyl pyrazine to a fluoro-trifluoromethyl pyridine (415) increased PXR activation, while also increasing clog P (values used from the publication) and decreased in vitro metabolic stability. Ultimately, 414 (JNJ-54717793) was selected in preference over 413 based on its lower EC50 value (85 ng/mL, corresponding to an ED50 of 1.3 mg/kg p.o.) in a rat ex vivo receptor occupancy study.
    When profiled in a rat 5 day toxicology study at doses or 100, 250, and 1000 mg/kg, 414 (JNJ-54717793) showed PXR activation as determined by decreased exposure and increased CYP3A1 mRNA levels. These results were confirmed in 14 day studies in mouse and rat at 200 mg/kg/day p.o. In the mouse, the Cmax values were 32 905 ng/mL on day 0 and 24 758 ng/mL on day 13, with corresponding AUC(0–24h) values of 225 157 on day 0 and 84 127 h ng/mL on day 13, corresponding to a 1.3-fold decrease in Cmax and a 2.7-fold decrease in AUC. In the rat, the decrease in exposure was more pronounced; the Cmax values were 30 900 (day 0), 8 800 (day 6), and 6 980 ng/mL (day 13), respectively, resulting in a 4.4-fold reduction. The corresponding AUC0–24h values were 38 600, 62 000, and 36 200 h ng/mL on days 0, 6, and 13, respectively, corresponding to an almost 11-fold reduction. In a 6 day dog study, there were no significant decreases in exposure, with Cmax of 15 100 ng/mL at the NOAEL (25 mg/kg), thus approximately half the level seen in the rat and mouse. Based on these data, 414 (JNJ-54717793) was selected as a development candidate.
    In summary, the literature SAR on PXR/CYP3A4 induction discussed here shows several interesting aspects and that it is feasible to reduce this undesired activity in most instances.
    One of the common strategies to reduce PXR activation is to reduce the lipophilicity of compounds. While this is not always successful, it is nevertheless a worthy one. Other noteworthy strategies include rigidification, exemplified by HCV NS5B (section 5.1); adding a sulfone, or sulfonamide, to an aromatic (phenyl) ring, exemplified by 11βHSD1 (section 5.2), RORγ (section 5.13); replacing a phenyl ring by polar aromatic heterocycles such pyridine, pyrazine, pyrimidine, or isoxazole, exemplified by 11βHSD1 (section 5.2) and smoothened (section 5.7), IDH1 (section 5.9); adding Cl or F or switching one to the other, exemplified by 11βHSD1 (section 5.2), RORγ (section 5.13), HBV capsid (section 5.15), EZH2 (section 5.16); replacing cycloalkyl groups by heterocycles, exemplified by 11βHSD1 (section 5.2), CFTR (section 5.12); fluorinating alkyl groups; adding a nitrile to an aromatic ring.

    6. Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As can be seen from this perspective, PXR can be activated by a wide variety of ligands with very broad structural diversity. The table below, Table 8, summarizes some of the key structural modifications observed from the analysis of the published work and can be considered as a quick guide of structural modifications worthy of consideration. Numerous strategies can be seen to be effective, including adding a neutral group (steric clash), adding a polar group, removing groups or truncating the structure, adding fluorine, removing fluorine, switching Cl to F and vice versa, reducing aromaticity while increasing polarity, replacing phenyl rings by heteroaromatics, and removing/diminishing HBA potential.
    Table 8. Summary of Some Key Chemotypes That Activate PXR (Example Ligand) And Key Structural Modifications Undertaken to Significantly Reduce PXR Activation (Optimized Structure)
    As can be seen, it can be difficult to define structural alerts; however, the potent PXR activators summarized in Table 8 serve to highlight some of the structural features that may be considered risk factors or structural alerts. However, benzylic groups are present frequently in PXR ligands and often form π-interaction with Trp299 in the hydrophobic cage and possibly edge-to-face or π–π interactions with other residues also in the hydrophobic cage, such as Phe288 and Tyr306. Furthermore, molecular features that induce a bent or folded conformation are often present in PXR ligands (e.g., S1P1 antagonists and OX1 antagonists), which also flags sulfones and sulfonamides as alerting moieties. In addition, benzylic substitution, e.g., by methyl or cyclopropyl, help to stabilize a bent conformation which often further enhances PXR binding.
    Other features include an H-bond acceptor in middle of molecule (which often interact with His407, Ser247, or Gln285) can also be key. A summary of some of these key structural elements is summarized in Figure 106.
    The authors recommend routine screening of PXR activity during drug discovery projects. This is most likely to be included as ad hoc screening or more systematically if PXR activity is found to be an issue. In this case, then a PXR activation or CYP induction assay should be added to the screening cascade to establish the SAR and to help design out the liability. In addition to screening for PXR, once it has been established that compounds from a series activate PXR, it is recommended to initiate computational chemistry activities, including docking and to cocrystallize ligands with PXR. While docking may be useful in some cases, especially if there are similarities to ligands that have been crystallized with PXR, it should always be borne in mind that multiple binding modes can exist and that ligands can alter their binding conformation or even flip. Therefore, the use of crystallography is highly recommended. Furthermore, it is beneficial to obtain structures of several ligands to establish a consistent binding mode and to understand if the structural modifications have altered the binding mode in any way.
    In terms of in vitro screening, there are several possibilities, as can been seen from the literature examples reviewed herein. A single concentration in vitro assay, for example, a PXR transactivation reporter gene assay is relatively straightforward. Compounds can be screened at 10 or 30 μM and ranked relative to rifampicin at 10 μM. In assays such as this, it is generally advisable to screen for function, i.e., activation, rather than binding, and to aim for very weak to no activity, i.e., no activation at 10 or even 30 μM. It is important to note that there are caveats. For example, the likely therapeutic concentrations should always be borne in mind, if estimated therapeutic concentrations are low then CYP3A4 induction may not be as problematic as anticipated. In addition to, or in place of single concentration activation assays, full dose–response assays may be preferred due to their higher information content. It is important that optimization focuses on increasing the EC50 and reducing % activation as both parameters are important. Furthermore, there is the potential that these in vitro assays can overestimate the induction potential; therefore, it is advisable to ensure follow up, lower throughput assays, such as human hepatocyte assays measuring CYP3A4 mRNA/activity (using hepatocytes from more than one donor). These assays measuring increases in CYP3A4 mRNA can be conducted with 24 or 48 h, incubation with compounds, although longer is generally required to measure increased CYP3A4 activity.(134) Subsequently, it is advisable to study compounds as early as possible in repeat dose studies (at least 4 or 5 days in duration) in preclinical species to evaluate the potential impact of any in vitro induction flag on the exposure following repeated administration. It is always worth bearing in mind the species differences and that a lack of decreased exposure in rodents does not necessarily mean this will be the case in humans. However, autoinduction (decreased exposure following repeated administration) in rodents is quite common and is important to investigate since it might complicate a drug development program by limiting the exposure that could be achieved in the toxicology studies.
    Finally, although PXR transactivation assays are widely used in drug discovery to assess the CYP3A induction potential of compounds, they are not optimal to predict the magnitude of a DDI (exposure changes). Therefore, they should be mainly used to identify PXR agonists and to bin, or rank order compounds, based on their potency to increase the transcription of CYP3A4. The work performed by Sinz et al. using 170 compounds suggested that PXR data combined with observed total plasma Cmax at therapeutic doses could help to categorize the potential risk of CYP3A4 induction.(110) This approach requires the estimated total plasma Cmax at therapeutic doses which is not readily available in early drug discovery. Due to the number of assumptions made with the use of total plasma Cmax as a relevant concentration for translation of the in vitro PXR data, this approach should be used for a qualitative assessment of the risk, e.g., to categorize as low, medium, or high. Although PXR assays are very useful to build SAR or bin compounds, they cannot accurately and quantitatively predict changes in exposure preclinically or clinically because of the inherent limitations associated with the assays (see the Introduction). Robust prediction of CYP3A4 induction in human based on in vitro data requires significant investment. Appropriate in vitro data (EC50/Emax in a physiologically relevant in vitro model) as well as information on disposition of drug candidates (Fu, expected active dose, expected plasma concentration at active dose, liver uptake, predicted portal vein concentration, potential role of metabolite(s), predicted gut lumen concentration for intestinal CYP3A4 induction, etc.) are essential to translate in vitro data to the in vivo situation, which requires considerable time. Therefore, it is always advisable to profile compounds in more definitive, lower throughput assays, such as human hepatocytes (for example, see Bayer thrombin inhibitors, section 5.10) on potentially interesting compounds to assess the risk of CYP induction in the clinic.
    In conclusion, this perspective has tried to highlight the role of PXR as an undesired activity in drug discovery. The recent advances in the use of PXR crystallography to allow the informed design of new compounds has greatly increased the ability to design out this activity. The structure-guided section highlights how this has been successfully used by several companies on a range of different targets. From this section and the empirical SAR section, it can be seen that there are many different chemotypes that can activate PXR and there are many ways in which to diminish this activity. It is hoped that this perspective will serve as a useful summary and starting point for anyone who encounters an issue with PXR. Finally, some examples of key structures that activate PXR and the successful structural modifications to reduce PXR activity are summarized in conjunction with a summary of some structural alerts and some practical recommendations and considerations to enable the assessment and screening of PXR issues.

    7. Addendum

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    While this manuscript was undergoing review, a paper detailing 14 new PXR structures appeared.(258) Given its relevance to this perspective, a brief discussion of the most salient points has been added in this section, with an annex to Table 2 (Table 9), with continued numbering. Of the 14 new structures, 1 is apo, 9 are with 1 ligand (although 2 have two copies of the same ligand), and 4 are with two (different) bound ligands.
    Table 9. Additional PXR Crystal Structures Deposited in PDB Whilst This Manuscript Was Undergoing Review
    The apo structure does not differ significantly from the previously reported structure so is not discussed further. Of the nine new ligands, three show covalent interactions, highlighting that two cysteine residues in the binding site, Cys207 and Cys3284, can be covalently labeled. This is the first time a covalent interaction has been observed. Furthermore, fipronil (420) targets Cys284 selectively, while pretilachlor (422) targets Cys207 selectively, and the third (tributyl tin, 423) labels both via two ligands in the pocket. The four structures with two ligands bound to the pocket are similar to entry 18 in Table 2, 4X1G, with TNC (68) and 17α-ethinylestradiol (68), as three of them contain an analogue of TNC (68) with estradiol (425) instead of 17α-ethinylestadiol (56).
    One of new structures, 7AXJ contains estradiol (425) in the presence of clotrimazole (417) and highlights that two ligands binding simultaneously can produce a synergistic effect on PXR activity. When bound on its own, one phenyl ring of clotrimazole (417) forms edge-to-face interactions with Tyr306 and an offset π–π interaction with Trp299, Figure 107. The imidazole of forms an edge-to-face withTrp299 and a H-bond with His327 (all hydrophobic cage, green). In addition there is an edge-to-face interaction with His407 (polar rim, blue) and the chlorophenyl rind of clotrimazole.
    When cobound with estradiol (425), Figure 107, clotrimazole (417) occupies a similar region of the pocket, i.e., in the hydrophobic cage, but is flipped so that the chlorophenyl ring forms a π–π interaction with Trp299 and an edge-to-face interaction with Tyr306, thereby losing the interaction with the polar rim. The ligands do not appear to form any particular interactions. The secondary alcohol of estradiol (425) forms two hydrogen bonds with PXR; one with the backbone carbonyl Asp205 (polar channel, magenta) and one with the guanidine moiety of Arg410 (polar rim, blue). An additional hydrogen bond is formed between the phenol of estradiol (425) and the side chain of Ser247 (polar rim, blue). In addition, there is movement to accommodate the two ligands, for example, the sidechains of His407 (polar rim, blue), Leu209 (polar channel, magenta), and Met323 (polar rim, blue), while there is some movement on the hydrophobic side (orange) versus the structure with clotrimazole (417) alone. In contrast, the hydrophobic cage shows minimal alteration.
    As mentioned, two druglike molecules, fipronil (420) and pretilachlor (422) form covalent bonds with PXR. Fipronil (420), Figure 108, interacts strongly with the hydrophobic cage, forming a π–π interaction between the trisubstituted phenyl ring and Phe288 and an edge-to-face interaction with Trp299. The trifluoromethyl group also forms hydrophobic interactions with Trp299 and Tyr306. The ligand extends out from the hydrophobic cage toward the polar rim (blue) where the trifluoromethyl sulfone O-atom interacts with His407 (polar rim, blue) and forms an intramolecular H-bond of the NH2 on the pyrazole. The nitrile on the pyrazole appears to form a covalent bond with Cys284, as discussed in the manuscript, with the C–S distance as 2.3 Å. However, this was not confirmed by mass spectrometry, potentially due to the covalent reversible nature of the interaction, which results in a short residence time.
    The structure with pretilachlor (422) is interesting in that it shows two copies of the ligand, one in black and one in gray, simultaneously bound, Figure 108, one of which (gray) is bound covalently. One molecule interacts with the hydrophobic cage (green), forming an edge-to-face interaction with Phe288, while the other is closer to the polar channel (magenta) and the hydrophobic side (orange) and forms a covalent bond with Cys207 on the polar channel (magenta). Comparison of the pretilachlor-bound structure with the apo structure reveals a significant movement of the protein. Furthermore pretilachlor is a potent and full agonist in the luciferase reporter assay used in this study, implying the covalent interaction locks PXR in an active conformation.
    The authors also highlight the importance of the hydrophobic cage, or aromatic cage as they termed it, in forming interactions with several ligands. This is exemplified in different ways for ligands such as ferutinin (419), oxadiazon (421), and α-zearalanol (424), Figure 109. For ferutinin (419), the cyclopentyl ring occupies the hydrophobic cage (green). The ligand also forms a hydrogen bonds with Gln285 and Glu321, via the phenol, (polar rim, blue) in addition to bridging water-mediated H-bonds, e.g., Ser247. In the case of oxadiazon (421), the t-Bu group interacts with Trp299, Phe288, and Tyr306 highlighting that π–π or edge-to-face interactions are not necessarily required to interact with the hydrophobic cage. In addition, the ligand also demonstrates halogen bonds can be effective in binding to PXR. Finally α-zearalanol (424) predominantly forms lipophilic contacts with the hydrophobic cage (green) but also makes a hydrogen bond with Gln285 (polar rim, blue) and partly interacts with the polar channel (magenta).
